title: ac.commutative algebra - A series that is algebraic?
body: This question is a follow-up of question A series that is rational? . Let $k=\mathbb F_q(T)$ . Can one prove (or disprove) that the series $\sum_{n\ge0}(1-TX^{q^n})Y^{q^n}\in k[[X,Y]]$ is algebraic over $k(X,Y)$ ? In the mentioned link it is proved that the series does not belong to $k(X,Y)$ . If the series would be $\sum_{n\ge0}(1-X^{q^n})Y^{q^n}$ , it is easy to prove... ac.commutative-algebra power-series Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 11, 2020 at 16:52 asked Jul 11, 2020 at 16:41 joaopa 4,358 1 1 gold badge 17 17 silver badges 24 24 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 1 13 $\begingroup$ The series is $f-Tg$ where $f=\sum_{n\geq0}Y^{q^n}$ and $g=\sum_{n\geq0}(XY)^{q^n}$. Both $f$ and $g$ are algebraic since $f^q-f=-Y$ and $g^q-g=-XY$. $\endgroup$ Laurent Moret-Bailly –  Laurent Moret-Bailly 2020-07-11 16:52:47 +00:00 Commented Jul 11, 2020 at 16:52 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
